Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Strain Engineered Mixed Ionic Electronic Conducting Solid Oxide Fuel Cell Anode Catalysts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1254453
Nicholas, Jason D.

Fuels cells are electrochemical devices used to convert the energy stored within the chemical bonds of the fuel into electrical energy and/or heat. Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFCs), which have efficiencies of 60-85%, highest of the hydrocarbon-based electricity production technologies, achieve this by allowing oxygen ions to pass through an electronically insulating solid membrane; and in the process producing electricity by forcing the oxygen electrons to circumvent the membrane via an external circuit. By electrochemically oxidizing fuel in this manner instead of combusting it, SOFCs have demonstrated combined heat and power efficiencies more than twice those obtained in conventional fossil fuel-fed power plants. Unlike other types of fuel cells that can only run on hydrogen, SOFCs can operate on a variety of fuels such as hydrogen, biogas, gasoline, natural gas, jet fuel, and methane.

With their ability to run on both hydrocarbon and hydrogen fuels, why have SOFCs not become a primary energy conversion solution? Two of the most daunting obstacles to SOFC commercialization are 1) a lack of SOFC electrode catalyst materials with desirable surface properties at operating temperatures less than 600C, and 2) a lack of catalytically active, high conductivity, redox stable, coking resistant, sulfur tolerant, SOFC anode materials which will allow SOFCs to operate on dry, commercially-widespread hydrocarbon fuels. Professor Jason Nicholas of Michigan State University believes that the pool of available materials may already contain those which will do the job, including mixed ionic electronic-conducting lanthanum strontium chromium magnesium oxides. The National Science Foundation is awarding the Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program Award to Nicholas to systematically evaluate the hypothesis that the necessary surface properties and the catalytic activity and selectivity of these mixed ionic oxides can be enhanced through the application of an external biaxial stress. Although thin film catalysts will initially be studied, the PI intends to fabricate and elucidate the behavior of nanocomposite SOFC anodes containing strain engineered catalysts by a number of standard methods. In addition, the investigator will develop a novel curvature relaxation measurement technique which will allow oxygen surface exchange measurements to be performed in situ and in operando without the distortions caused by electrodes, yielding data not previously available.

The proposed work will advance the field of catalysis by systematically elucidating, for the first time, the full relationship between stress, structure, electrochemical properties, temperature, and oxygen partial pressure in a SOFC anode electrocatalyst. The investigator plans a wide program of educational outreach activities as a feature of the CAREER award, extending to high school students, undergraduates and teachers. A specific activity will be to provide mid-Michigan Girl Scouts with an annual Michigan State University visit day aimed at introducing K-12 girls to the Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As stated in the Project Outcomes Report, over the life of this award, a new, non-contact, in situ, current-collector-free Curvature Relaxation technique was developed to simultaneously measure a thin film's biaxial modulus, Young's modulus, thermal expansion coefficient, thermo-chemical expansion coefficient, oxygen nonstoichiometry, chemical oxygen surface exchange coefficient, oxygen surface exchange resistance, thermal stress, chemical stress, thermal strain, and chemical strain for the first time. In addition to producing valuable materials property measurements on several state-of-the-art oxygen ion exchange catalysts (such as lanthanum strontium ferrite, praseodymium doped ceria, and strontium iron ferrite), use of this technique showed that the precious metal current collectors or impurities commonly found in alternative measurement techniques (such as Electrical Conductivity Relaxation) can artificially boost the measured oxygen surface exchange coefficient (such that it no longer reflects the behavior of the oxygen exchange catalyst of interest). As part of this award, the impact of precursor solution dispersants and ceria pre-infiltration on the performance of infiltrated Solid Oxide Fuel Cell cathodes was evaluated; resulting in the production of some of the world's best-performing nano-composite Solid Oxide Fuel Cell electrodes (the cathodes produced here had open circuit polarization resistances of 0.1 Ohm*cm at 550C). These nano-composite cathodes were provided to two Solid Oxide Fuel Cell manufacturers for evaluation. As part of this award, Density Functional Theory modeling of the electronic rearrangements that occur when oxygen vacancies are formed in Solid Oxide Fuel Cell oxygen exchange catalysts, and how those rearrangements impact the concentration, mobility, and conductivity of oxygen ions was conducted. This modeling work identified a new phase, cubic strontium ferrite, which (if it could be stabilized at Solid Oxide Fuel Cell operating temperatures through strain, doping, other means) is predicted to have an oxygen ion conductivity greater than the current state-of-the-art rhombohedral lanthanum strontium ferrite oxygen exchange catalysts used in Solid Oxide Fuel Cell cathodes. As part of this award, PI Nicholas founded an annual Michigan State University (MSU) "Girl STEM Demo Day" that grew from 100 to 500 participants over several years, had inner city girls bussed to the event, and had an average anonymous event rating of 3.8/4. After 3 years of leading the event, in 2016 PI Nicholas handed this activity off to a new MSU Women in Engineering, Recruitment and K-12 Outreach Office that opened it to all 4-8th grade girls and rebranded it as an "Introduce a Girl to Engineering Day". This event still occurs each February. As part of this award, PI Nicholas founded and continues to organize a biannual Electrochemical Society Symposium on "Mechanical-Electrochemical Coupling in Energy Related Materials and Devices" that had over 350 participants when it was last held in 2018. PI Nicholas also founded and continues to serve as a faculty advisor for the Chemical Engineering and Materials Science Graduate Student Association at Michigan State University. In summary, this award produced 14 high-impact, peer-reviewed publications, directly supported the work of two PhD students/two undergraduate students/one high school student, and helped set-up PI Nicholas for a career's worth of Solid Oxide Fuel Cell, ion transport, catalysis, and Materials Science discoveries.


Last Modified: 06/12/2020
Modified by: Jason D Nicholas

As part of this award, the impact of precursor solution dispersants and ceria pre-infiltration on the performance of infiltrated Solid Oxide Fuel Cell cathodes was evaluated; resulting in the production of some of the world's best-performing nano-composite Solid Oxide Fuel Cell electrodes (the cathodes produced here had open circuit polarization resistances of 0.1 Ohm*cm at 550C). These nano-composite cathodes were provided to two Solid Oxide Fuel Cell manufacturers for evaluation. As part of this award, Density Functional Theory modeling of the electronic rearrangements that occur when oxygen vacancies are formed in Solid Oxide Fuel Cell oxygen exchange catalysts, and how those rearrangements impact the concentration, mobility, and conductivity of oxygen ions was conducted. This modeling work identified a new phase, cubic strontium ferrite, which (if it could be stabilized at Solid Oxide Fuel Cell operating temperatures through strain, doping, other means) is predicted to have an oxygen ion conductivity greater than the current state-of-the-art rhombohedral lanthanum strontium ferrite oxygen exchange catalysts used in Solid Oxide Fuel Cell cathodes. As part of this award, PI Nicholas founded an annual Michigan State University (MSU) "Girl STEM Demo Day" that grew from 100 to 500 participants over several years, had inner city girls bussed to the event, and had an average anonymous event rating of 3.8/4. After 3 years of leading the event, in 2016 PI Nicholas handed this activity off to a new MSU Women in Engineering, Recruitment and K-12 Outreach Office that opened it to all 4-8th grade girls and rebranded it as an "Introduce a Girl to Engineering Day". This event still occurs each February. As part of this award, PI Nicholas founded and continues to organize a biannual Electrochemical Society Symposium on "Mechanical-Electrochemical Coupling in Energy Related Materials and Devices" that had over 350 participants when it was last held in 2018. PI Nicholas also founded and continues to serve as a faculty advisor for the Chemical Engineering and Materials Science Graduate Student Association at Michigan State University.
